description: From Middle English repugnaunt, from Old French repugnant, borrowed from Latin repugnans, present participle of repugnare (“to oppose, to fight against”), from re- (“back, against”) + pugnare (“to fight”); see pugnacious.

adjectives.description: repugnant (comparative more repugnant, superlative most repugnant)

entries.meaning: Offensive or repulsive; arousing disgust or aversion.
